item.title: Preparation for using the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud
item.description:
We will use the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud for some of the labs. Amazon supports HEIG-VD by a generous grant in their AWS Educate program. Amazon gives to each HEIG-VD student a credit of $100 to use its cloud resources.

Amazon designed AWS for companies, not students. When you create an account to start using AWS, Amazon requires a credit card that it can bill for future usage charges. Because the charges will be covered by the AWS Educate credit you receive, the credit card will not be billed. We encourage you strongly to create an account with a credit card, as it allows you to keep the account and any remaining credit after the course and use it for your own projects. If however you don’t have a credit card, contact us and we will send you separate instructions. In this case you will not be able to keep the account after the course.

Note that in Switzerland PostFinance bank offers a prepaid credit card, PostFinance MasterCard Value, free of charge for students.

To participate in AWS Educate you first create an AWS account, like a regular customer would do, then you apply for AWS Educate. When you are approved by Amazon they will send you a credit code. Finally you put the credit code in your AWS account.

Note that the AWS Educate credit is per student and year, not per course. So if you have another cloud-based course the same year, be careful not to spend your whole credit in one course.

To create an AWS account and apply for AWS Educate follow these steps:

  1. Create an AWS account. Go to http://aws.amazon.com. Click on Create an AWS Account and follow the instructions.

    Caution: You will be asked to select your support plan. Do not change the default selection Basic (free). Developer support is not covered by AWS Educate and you would have to pay out of your your own pocket.

    After you have created the account write down the Account Id to use it later when applying for AWS Educate. Go to http://console.aws.amazon.com and log in. Click on the dropdown menu with your name in the upper right corner and select My Account. Under Account Setting you will see your Account Id.

  2. Apply for AWS Educate.

    a. Go to http://awseducate.com/. Click on Apply Now.

    b. On the following page click on Apply for AWS Educate for Students.

    c. On the page titled Choose Your Role select Student and click Next.

    d. On the page titled Fill out Application provide the following information.

    • Institution Name: Start typing HEIG-VD. The field has auto-complete enabled and will suggest HEIG-VD (La Haute Ecole d’Ing√©nierie et de Gestion du Canton de Vaud). Select it.

    • Country: Switzerland

    • City: Yverdon

    • Field of Study: Computer Science

    • First Name: Your first name

    • Last Name: Your last name

    • Email: Your HEIG-VD email address. That is the address that terminates with @heig-vd.ch.

    • AWS Account ID: Fill in the Account Id you wrote down earlier.

    • Grade Level: Undergraduate-Adv Courses

    • Graduation Year: The year when you will graduate.

    • Graduation Month: The month when you will graduate.

    Click on Next.

    e. Amazon will send a verification email to your HEIG-VD address. Enter the code on the page titled Verify Email Address, click on I am not a robot and click Next.

    f. Follow the remaining instructions to complete the process.

    g. After you submitted the application you will receive an email that the application was received by Amazon. Amazon will review your application, which can take up to three business days.

  3. Upon acceptance you will receive a welcome email by Amazon. It will contain a credit code. To put it into your AWS account, login to your account. Navigate using the drop-down menu with your name in the upper right corner to Billing & Cost Management. Then select Credits from the left menu and enter the code that you have received.

Quick guide to Markdown
item.description:
What is Markdown

Markdown is a very lightweight markup language (like HTML) that is being used by a lot of people. It’s fast, efficient, really easy to read and compatible pretty much everywhere.

There are many websites and examples where the text is written in Markdown:

  • READMEs and documentation files on github are in Markdown (extension .md)
  • Some of the documentation on Moodle is written in Markdown.
  • This very article is also written in Markdown (and obviously all the other articles on this blog).

Quick guide

Here is a quick guide for the syntax of Markdown

Titles

To make a title, you need to use the # character. It works like HTML title, h1 is the biggest, then comes h2, then h3… In Markdown, it’s the number of # you put that defines the level:

# h1
## h2
### h3 
#### h4 
...

So, for example:

# My big title
## My not so big title
### My small title
...

will give you:

My big title

My not so big title

My small title

Etc…

Note: be sure to put a <space> between the last # and your first letter. If you don’t, it may give you weird results on some browsers.

Text modification

These modifications would be this or this. Once again, to do this in Markdown, it’s really easy.

Bold

**Your text**

or

__Your text__

Both of these will give the same result.

Italic

*Your text*

or

_Your text_

Quite easy.

Note: Usually, we want to separate the special characters and the text with a <space>, like with titles, here we do the opposite. We want the text to be right after the character!

Lists

  • This
  • Or this
    • Or that
    • And that too
      • Maybe this too?

How to do this? Once again, it’s simple, it’s the * character.

* This
* Or this 
 * Or that
 * And that too
   * Maybe this too?

To create a list, put a star, followed by a <space> and your text. To create a new element on the same of the list, just do the same and finally, to indent it, use a tab or 2 <spaces> characters before putting the first star.

* 1
* 2
  * 2.5 <-- Tab or two spaces before the star

Code

This type of “box”:

This one here

is used to type in “code”. We use if for commands, for instance:

$ sudo reboot

To do so, just start your line with a <tab> or 4 <spaces>. (Always use tab)

Not easy to explain 
    new tab
        other tab

You can also indent this with other <tab> characters.

Quote

This is a quote:

Hey, I am a quote

To create this, just start your line with >.

> a quote
> a second quote

Images and links

You can add images and links in your documents with these commands:

Link

[Descrition](http://your_url.ch)

Image

![Description](http://your_image.png)

Obviously, you can create absolute or relatives links, meaning you can link something by it’s url or in your working directory, like this:

# Your image is in the "img" folder
![My super image](./img/super_image.png)

HTML

Markdown is made to work with HTML, you can type in HTML wherever you want. For instance, there is no support for tables in Markdown, so if you want to create one, you can use html tags.

<table>
    <tr>
        <th>header1</th>
    </tr>
    <tr>
        <td>Content1</td>
    </tr>
<table>

So be careful, every time you want to write text between < and > (Like an html tag), it will be interpreted as a HTML tag and may give you strange behaviours… Unless you escape it!

Escaping characters

You should have noticed, Markdown is really easy, we work a lot with tabulations, *, and _. But what happens when you write something like:

your_user_name

it will give you this: your_user_name

The _ characters will be used to render the “user” text in italic, because they have not been escaped. We need to give the indication that we want the _ to be interpreted as text. How to do this? We use the escape character, .

your\_user_name

will give you: your_user_name.

We could obviously also escape the second one:

your\_user\_name

but it’s not necessary, because a simple _ will be interpreted as text anyway.

The same happens when you want to use a star, let’s say:

rm -r *march.*

rm -r march.

The stars were not treated as text, so escaping the first star should help, like we did previously.

rm -r \*march.* OR rm -r \*march.\*

This gives you: rm -r *march.*

There are some other cases where you need to escape the escape character itself to print it, but that should be enough information for now :)

And also, the same applies to the < and > characters, if you want to print this:

<my_tag>

You have to write it like this:

\<my_tag>

So you can see it (otherwise it will considered like a HTML tag and it won’t be printed. Even worse, depending on the tag, it may even give you problems, because it will be expecting the closing tag, like </my_tag>.

Markdown tools

Here is a short list of Markdown editors you should use:

Windows:

  • Markdown pad

Mac:

  • MacDown

Linux:

  • Short list of them

item.title: Integrate your virtual machine with your local machine
item.description:
VirtualBox customisations

Install the VirtualBox Guest Additions

By default, a virtualised OS doest not know that it is running in a virtual machine. It believes that it is installed directly on top of hardware and that it is in total control of the keyboard and mouse, for example. Well, that’s not true. The VirtualBox tools are meant to be installed on a VM, to enable some options that are not possible otherwise, like correct handling of the mouse, sharing of files between guest and host and others.

In the menu of VirtualBox -> Devices -> Insert Guest Additions CD Image…

  • Select Run
  • Type in your password

  • reboot

    $ sudo reboot

You now can run the VM in a window with proper handling of the mouse or you can run it in fullscreen mode (Host + f).

Enable bidirectional clipboard (copy & paste between host and guest)

This is a very useful tool that will allow you to share your clipboard between your host and your guest machines. To do this, go to Devices, Shared Clipboard, Bidirectional.

You probably need to install the VirtualBox Guest Additions, as explained in the previous chapter.

Pro tips: usually, the ctrl+c and ctrl+v do not work well between the host and the guest, use right click copy and right click paste.

Enable sharing of folders between the Linux VM and your host machine

Normally, as the VM runs its own operating system, your host machines sees the VM as a completely separate machine. To transfer files between host and guest you would need to transfer the files over the network, for example using a file transfer protocol that is difficult to set up. Luckily there is a simpler solution: VirtualBox offers an option to share a folder between host and guest. This file sharing works similar to network file sharing, but is much easier to set up.

On the command line of the Linux VM run the following commands and answer all questions with the default values:

$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get upgrade
$ sudo apt-get install dkms

Reboot the VM:

$ sudo shutdown -r now (or sudo reboot)

Navigate to Devices > Insert Guest Additions CD image… This will mount a CD on your Desktop.

You can run find the CD on the file explorer (name may change depending on your Desktop version). You should have something like:

  • Open Autorun Prompt
  • Run Program / script

If not, double click on the VBoxLinuxAdditions.sh.

This will open a terminal and install some of the needed packages. You can restart your machine after that.

$ sudo reboot

Share a folder on the host machine: Navigate to Devices > Shared Folder Settings… Click on Add. Select the folder you want to share, let’s say you just created a folder called C:\Users\Your_Name\ADS (you can put it wherever you want, like My Documents or your Desktop).

  • Enable Read-only if you want to prevent accidental modification of your files from Linux. (Not recommended if you want to share files from your VM to your host machine).
  • Enable Auto-mount

Click OK.

Now, on your VM, type in this command (it will add you on the group that can work with the shared folder):

# Use your username, administrator by default if you followed the guide.
$ sudo adduser <username> vboxsf

Now you only need to restart your machine, from now on, Ubuntu will auto-mount your shared folder.

Install an other GUI for your Ubuntu Linux

The GUI you get with Ubuntu (called Unity) tends to run slowly inside a VM. Fortunately in the Linux world you can choose between many different GUIs. Some of them are faster, and some of them try to emulate the look and feel of Windows.

The creators of Ubuntu maintain a list of the different GUI for Ubuntu and how to install them. We recommend Xfce or LXDE, both are pretty light and simple to use.

You can also have different GUIs installed at the same time and pick the one you want when you log in. In the login page there is a white circle next to your name, clicking on it will allow you to choose the one you want. If this circle is not there, sometimes the icon is somewhere else, like on the right top of the screen.

Installing Xfce

Install only the desktop environment

$ sudo apt-get install xubuntu-desktop
$ sudo reboot

You may need to change the keyboard configuration

Installing LXDE

$ sudo apt-get install lxde 
$ sudo reboot

item.title: Use SSH to log into your virtual machine
item.description:
Professional developers and system administrators working with Linux servers often re-create the server environment on their local machine by running Linux with the server applications in a virtual machine. They are used to work on the command line and they connect to the remote servers via SSH. To access the local Linux VM they use SSH as well instead of using the VirtualBox/VMware console, because they can keep using the same keystrokes and work faster. In this article we explain how to set up SSH to connect from a host machine to a Linux guest VM.

(For Windows users only:) Install Git bash

To connect to another machine via SSH you need an SSH client program on your Windows machine. A popular option is to use Putty, but we recommend Git Bash instead as it is easier to use. Git Bash has also the nice feature that it provides an emulation of the Bash shell and allows you (more or less) to use Linux commands from a terminal on a Windows machine.

  1. Download Git Bash

    Download it here: https://git-for-windows.github.io/

  2. Installation

    • Select components: default
    • Use Git from Git bash only
    • Checkout-windows Style, commit Unix-style line endings
    • Use MinTTY

  3. Launch it

    You should now have the program called Git Bash. In the terminal you can work with the directory /home/your_name, it is mapped to the directory C:\Users\your_name\ in the real file system. So if you were doing for example on Linux:

    # Linux: Go to the SSH configuration directory 
$ cd ~/.ssh
$ pwd
/home/administrator/.ssh

    you can do the equivalent in Bash shell on Windows

    # Bash shell on Windows: Go to the SSH configuration directory
$ cd ~/.ssh
$ pwd
/c/Users/your_name/.ssh

You should now be able to follow the rest of the instructions on how to set up SSH.

Caution: When you are asked in a lab to work with Bash (command line or scripts), don’t use Git Bash to do the lab, as it is not a real Bash shell. Use it only to connect to a machine where a real Bash shell is running.

Configure the virtualization software to forward port 2222 to port 22

In this section we change the networking configuration of the virtualization software so that the SSH client on your host can connect to the SSH server on your guest VM.

Note that the configuration is different if you are using VirtualBox or VMware, as the networking component attaching the virtual machine to your host works differently. In the following we describe the configuration of VirtualBox.

Configure the networking of the virtual machine to forward incoming connections to port 2222 of address 127.0.0.1 to the SSH port (=22) of the virtual machine:

  • Navigate to Settings > Network > Adapter 1.
  • For Attached to: choose NAT.
  • Click on Port Forwarding. Create a rule that maps incoming TCP connections on host IP 127.0.0.1, port 2222 to guest port 22.

To connect to your Linux machine via SSH an SSH server needs to run on it. The SSH server should have been installed already when you installed Linux, but let’s check nonetheless. Open a command line on your VM and type:

$ sudo apt-get update
$ sudo apt-get install openssh-server

Create a keypair

There are generally two ways to log into a machine with SSH:

  • Authenticate by providing a username and password
  • Authenticate by providing a username and a keypair

Keypairs have a big advantage: they are much harder to crack for an adversary (this improves security a lot). Keypairs can be themselves protected by a password, but this is optional. When using a keypair you can choose to log into a machine without needing to type a password (this decreases security slightly).

In this section we describe how to set up authentication with a (passwordless) keypair. Here is an overview of the procedure:

  1. Log into the Linux VM using username and password.
  2. On the Linux VM create an SSH configuration directory and generate a keypair.
  3. On the host machine create an SSH configuration directory and transfer the private key of the keypair to the host machine.
  4. Use the new keypair to login.

In the following we explain the steps in more detail.

Log into the Linux VM using username and password

Open a terminal on your host and type:

    $ ssh -p 2222 administrator@127.0.0.1

As you are using SSH for the first time to connect to a new host, SSH will print a warning like this:

RSA key fingerprint is xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx.
Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no)? yes

This is completely normal, so just type yes.

If it works, you will see the command line prompt of the Linux VM, which should look like this:

administrator@ubuntu:~$

You are now logged into the Linux VM via SSH and every command you type in this terminal will be executed on the Linux VM.

On the Linux VM create an SSH configuration directory and generate a keypair

This involves the following steps:

  1. Create the SSH configuration directory ~/.ssh and protect it from outside access

    $ mkdir ~/.ssh
$ chmod go-rwx ~/.ssh

  2. Create a new keypair which will become your personal authentication token. Use your HEIG-VD email address to identify the key.

    $ ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your.name@heig-vd.ch"
Generating public/private rsa key pair.
Enter file in which to save the key (/home/administrator/.ssh/id_rsa): 
Created directory '/home/administrator/.ssh'.
Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase): #Press ENTER
Enter same passphrase again: #Press ENTER 
Your identification has been saved in /home/administrator/.ssh/id_rsa.
Your public key has been saved in /home/administrator/.ssh/id_rsa.pub.
The key fingerprint is:
xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx:xx: your.name@heig-vd.ch
The key's randomart image is:
+--[ RSA 4096]----+
|         .       |
|        . .      |
|         . .     |
|      .   ...    |
|     . .So...    |
|      o o=o. +   |
|       o..E.o .  |
|        .+ *.    |
|        ..+o.    |
+-----------------+

    Your private key can now be found in the file id_rsa, your public key is in the file id_rsa.pub. Both keys are plain text files.

  3. You now need to add your public key to the file authorized_keys (which does not yet exist). Simply copy your public key to a new file called authorized_keys:

    $ cp ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub ~/.ssh/authorized_keys

On the host machine create an SSH configuration directory and transfer the private key of the keypair to the host machine.

On your host machine open a second terminal. Create the SSH configuration directory ~/.ssh and protect it from outside access

    $ mkdir ~/.ssh
    $ chmod go-rwx ~/.ssh

To transfer the private key from guest to host we will use your host machine’s clipboard (copy and paste):

  1. On the Linux VM display the key using the cat command:

    $ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa
-----BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY-----
...............................
...............................
-----END RSA PRIVATE KEY-----

    Select the text and copy it to the clipboard.

  2. On the host machine, use the nano text editor create a new file id_rsa in the directory ~/.ssh:

    $ nano ~/.ssh/id_rsa

Paste the content of the clipboard into the editor. Type Ctrl-O to save the file and Ctrl-X to exit the editor.

  1. On the Linux VM you can now log out:

    $ exit 
# Will close the ssh connection

Use the new keypair to login.

You should be able to connect to your Linux VM without needing to specify a password, like this:

    $ ssh -p 2222 administrator@127.0.0.1
    Welcome to Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS (GNU/Linux 3.13.0-44-generic x86_64)
    [...]
    administrator@ubuntu:~$

item.title: Install Linux on a VM
item.description:
Motivation

Developers and system administrators often need to re-create on their personal workstation the server environment they are working on. Servers often run Linux as operating system while for personal workstations Windows or Mac OS X is prevalent. Having a separate workstation for the server OS or installing the server OS via multi-boot is a hassle. Creating a virtual machine provides a quick way to run a new OS alongside the existing one. This document will show you how to install Ubuntu Linux in a virtual machine.

Create an Ubuntu Desktop VM

Usually, you can get two types of ISOs when you want to install an Ubuntu image:

  • Server version
  • Desktop version

The main difference is, the Ubuntu server version is meant to be used on server machines, so there is no graphical user interface whereas the desktop version has a GUI and ist meant to be used on a personal workstation. The server version has fewer packages than the desktop version and is approximately half the size.

Normally experienced developers and sytem administrators install the server version because they will work on the command line and don’t need the overhead of the GUI. As you are only getting started with the command line it is helpful to have the GUI in the beginning, so we recommend you install the desktop version.

  1. Download Ubuntu Desktop, version 14.04 LTS 64 bit from the Ubuntu website or the swiss mirror. You need to pick the desktop version, which should be called ubuntu-14.04-desktop-amd64.iso.

  2. Install your VM with your virtualization software. Pick the iso you previously downloaded as the source (also called CD image). If you are using VMware, don’t use the “easy install” option.

    • Choose language: leave default (English)

    • Installation options: Install Ubuntu (Install Ubuntu)

    • Erase Disk and install Ubuntu (Install Now)

    • Where are you (Zurich) (Should be by default)

    • Configure the keyboard: Switzerland > Switzerland - Switzerland - French (Switzerland)

    • Set up users and passwords - A user account will be created for you:

      • Full name: your full name
      • Your computer’s name: default
      • Username for your account: administrator
      • Password: invent a password
      • Encrypt your home directory?: leave default (No)

    • Finish the installation: Continue

    The installation finishes and the VM reboots. After booting you should see the Linux login prompt.
